briefdescription.para: Internal reference to the OpenGL texture to draw. Set in SetTexture() and used in paintGL().
Drawing matrix (defaults to identity)
Buffer to load images into RAM before sending them to the display.
Connected color manager.
Color management service.
Internal color transform storage.
ViewerGLWidget Constructor.
Set an image to load and display on screen.
Disconnect a ColorManager (equivalent to ConnectColorManager(nullptr))
Access currently connected ColorManager (nullptr if none)
Get current color transform.
Get menu that can be used to select the display transform.
Get menu that can be used to select the view transform.
Get menu that can be used to select the look transform.
Set the transformation matrix to draw with.

detaileddescription.para: Set this if you want the drawing to pass through some sort of transform (most of the time you won't want this).

briefdescription.para: Enables or disables whether this color at the cursor should be emitted.

detaileddescription.para: Since tracking the mouse every movement, reading pixels, and doing color transforms are processor intensive, we have an option for it. Ideally, this should be connected to a PixelSamplerPanel::visibilityChanged signal so that it can automatically be enabled when the user is pixel sampling and disabled for optimization when they're not.

briefdescription.para: Overrides the image with the load buffer of another ViewerGLWidget.

detaileddescription.para: If there are multiple ViewerGLWidgets showing the same thing, this is faster than decoding the image from file each time.

briefdescription.para: Replaces the color transform with a new one.
Connect a ColorManager (ColorManagers usually belong to the Project)
Signal emitted when the user starts dragging from the viewer.
Signal emitted when cursor color is enabled and the user's mouse position changes.
Signal emitted when a buffer is loaded from file into memory.

detaileddescription.para: This buffer will be the direct output of the renderer in reference space in CPU memory.
Connect this to the SetImageFromLoadBuffer() slot of another ViewerGLWidget to show the same thing

briefdescription.para: Emitted when the color processor changes.
Emitted when a new color manager is connected.
Override the mouse press event simply to emit the DragStarted() signal.
Override mouse move to provide functionality for.
Initialize function to set up the OpenGL context upon its construction.

detaileddescription.para: Currently primarily used to regenerate the pipeline shader used for drawing.

briefdescription.para: Paint function to display the texture (received in SetTexture()) on screen.

detaileddescription.para: Simple OpenGL drawing function for painting the texture on screen. Standardized around OpenGL ES 3.2 Core.

briefdescription.para: Provides access to the color processor (nullptr if none is set)
Enables a context menu that allows simple access to the DVL pipeline.
Function called whenever the processor changes.

detaileddescription.para: Default functionality is just to call update()

briefdescription.para: Slot to connect just before the OpenGL context is destroyed to clean up resources.
Sets all color settings to the defaults pertaining to this configuration.
The default context menu shown.
If GetDisplayMenu() is called with auto_connect set to true, it will be connected to this.
If GetViewMenu() is called with auto_connect set to true, it will be connected to this.
If GetLookMenu() is called with auto_connect set to true, it will be connected to this.
Call this if this user has selected a different display/view/look to recreate the processor.
Cleanup function.
The inner display/rendering widget of a Viewer class.

detaileddescription.para: Actual composition occurs elsewhere offscreen and multithreaded, so its main purpose is receiving a finalized OpenGL texture and displaying it.

The main entry point is SetTexture() which will receive an OpenGL texture ID, store it, and then call update() to draw it on screen. The drawing function is in paintGL() (called during the update() process by Qt) and is fairly simple OpenGL drawing code standardized around OpenGL ES 3.2 Core.

If the texture has been modified and you're 100% sure this widget is using the same texture object, it's possible to call update() directly to trigger a repaint, however this is not recommended. If you are not 100% sure it'll be the same texture object, use SetTexture() since it will nearly always be faster to just set it than to check and set it.
